label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, May 14, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, requesting news of her brother, Laddie Sanford, praising her idea to send their children to live with their sister-in-law, Olive, in New Orleans, Louisiana, and lamenting their lack of shore leave. Sidney continues in his letter to describe his brother, Morris’s, poor health and reminiscing on a trip they took through the Blue Ridge Mountains.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
May 14, 1943
Deer Gertie, 
I received your letter mailed on the seventh this morning. This
was the first letter I had received in a week as I hed received your last
letter on the seventh of this month. Naturally I was delighted to hear from
you, but could not underttand your remarks about being stuck in Washington
all Summer. I thought everything was fixed for you to join the Waacs, and
that you were leaving shortly to go to a camp and become a colonel. Won't
your organization give you permission to leave. I was under the impression
you had arranged everything in sinister fashion at a tea party where you
had brought the heads of the Waacs and your own Boss together for the
final details.
Couasin Annas Ewing death is a crime. He and she were such lovely
persons, I liked them so much and am genuinely sorry that they are gone. I will
always remember them in him sorrounded by their children and grand children
for when they lived and breathed. I suppose their lives were very hap y ones,
more so than many others in that they gave so much pleasure to others. Y ou
were wonderful to go to the funeral as tired as you are sweetheart, and I admire
you for doing so.
Dinner at Polly's is of course like stepping into another world.
The war, servants and money problems are dropped behind and all that is gold
glitters and all that glitters is gold.A real " let them eat cake if they
have no bread " world. I could take a little of it now myself. From your
discription of her summer I gather and am confirmed in my opinion that America
thinks the war is won, and that only the drones will continue to work and
slave at their jobs. I wish that I could depend on their hopes. You said
you were the only Sanford present and it raised the question in my mind
where Laddie is now. Has he been sent abroad or is he still in the States.
And what of Mary , is she with him or has she taken ajobh. I have not heard 
anything about them and hope they are well.
I think your idea of the children going to New Orleans is a brain
Wave and very fine. However I do not know whether they will have enough
servants to handle Miss Evans and two children end whether they will be able
to get them. You see Olive has never run a house like that before where
she has white nurses with trays and so many children not her own. However
if she will take them[,]which I think she will it would be wonderful for them
to see Southern life and a different way of living. Landine will hate it,
that I can promise you. You will receive letters that there are no nice
children etc. It will do her a hell of a lot of good, I think and hope.
No leave is being granted to anyone out here unless they have a
reason like their Father, Mother and Wife dying and no one to settle the
estate. Then you are given ten days to go back[,]and [are] admonished that you had
better not miss the boat either. However I hear gossip to the effect that
[End Page 1]
after two and a half years servcie in the island you will be given leave, so in
a year and four months or rather a yea[R] and ten nonths I will be knocking at
your door.
I go to the hospital every day and see Morris during my lu[n]ch hour.
He is feeling about hhe sane, although the doctors say there is nothing wrong
with him. They have taken a test of his blood and a cardigraph of his heart
and everything appears to be in working order. I sup ose he is just tired as
the doctor told his that at forty you have to begin taking care of yourself
and stop working when you are exhausted as you will only do damage to your
health it you keep on. It is very funny when he is not here as I am handling
his affairs as well as my own. You would apprecaite the situation if you could
see it after the [scratched through] we s ent in the little office at Medway with the
papers heaped on the desk. I think Morris will be a[L]lowed to leave this Sunday
and will than stay in bed at the apartment for a few days before returning to
work.
Your discription of the country with the wind blowing and the blossom
inx the trees was lovely . I reme ber well how superb those blue ridge
mountains were when we motroed there last fall a year ago. How they flamed
with color and we thought what a wonderful place to live. Do you remember
the funny old house we looked at with the enormous old rooms and staricase
that the women assured us floated. It had vey short rises to the steps and
even I was able to go up without puffing. Outside there were quaint bu@1nge
and a wonderful old kitchen. We discussed how wverything should be done over
You know I think the greatest pleasure in new places is the discussing of how
it should he done over , and not the doing over or acutally living in the
house.
My back it Ok again and the world is very fine. Today the sun is
shinning after a stormy night and pouring rain. There is a freshness in
the air, and a clxeaness[,]so that the mountains stand out and the cane in
the fields stretching to the distant ridges seems very green. I would like
to be riding ahorse in bracing autmn air and smell the smell of wood smoke
and damp leaves. You would like to be smelling salt water, and see the
breakers curl on the beach, and feel hot sun on your back and roll onover
slowly stretching and gurgling with pleasure at doing nothing in a lovely
place. Perhaps some day we will he able to.
Goodbye darling, all my love goes to you.
Sidney Legendre
[End Page 2]
